I'm trying to create a recursive-descent parser where I can prove that the parser terminates. For this, ever successfully parsed piece needs evidence that it "made progress". I'm now trying to implement a method that constructs a parser for string literals (sensibly called literal). I want to be able to call literal "||" at the call-site, but I need proof that the string is not empty to construct the parser properly.

I tried declaring the proof as an implicit parameter like this: 

def literal (literal: String) {nonEmptyProof: literal.length > 0} : Parser String := ...

This however, leads to the following error when trying to call the method with a string only: don't know how to synthesize implicit argument @literal "(".

Does anyone have an idea on how I can solve this or a link to a resource that explains how implicit arguments are synthesized in lean?
Implicit arguments aren't synthesized, unless they are referred to from another argument, like {x : Nat} (hx : x < 5)

I suspect that you have to tell lean how to prove that the assumption is satisfied. Or at least make a guess at how your assumption will be proved. For instance:

def literal (literal: String) (nonEmptyProof: literal.length > 0 := by decide) : Nat := literal.length

#eval literal "g"  -- 1

#eval literal ""
/-
tactic 'decide' proved that the proposition
  "".length > 0
is false
-/
For parser proofs, you might want to look at https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/data/buffer/parser/basic.html.
Note the explicit arguments for nonEmptyProof and the := by decide informing Lean that, should you not provide that argument, it should try to prove it using by decide.
Proof obligations about the parser itself were resolved using typeclasses, as suggested by Rob.
Wow, thanks for all the information! That's a great help! :)
Rodney McKay has marked this topic as resolved.
